text:
CURT NEWTON: All right,
welcome, everyone. We're so glad you've joined us.

Thanks for taking an
hour-ish to spend with us,

learn about some of
the amazing materials that MIT has created
and is sharing openly

to help you learn climate. This is a presentation
that draws

on the work of the MIT
Environmental Solutions Initiative, MIT OpenCourseWare
and MITx Online.

And this presentation is part
of International Open Access Week which this year has the
theme Open for Climate Justice.

They've got a great
assortment of events happening all week
long, and I encourage you to check those out.

Maybe you found out about this
through International Open Access Week, maybe
through other channels,

but definitely see some
of the other things that are going on this week.

It's-- I expect
will be of interest. I'd like to begin by introducing
your speakers, Sylvia, Dana.

Sylvia, you want to say hello? SYLVIA SCHARF: Sure, since
I seem to be listed first. Hi, my name is Sylvia Scharf.

And I'm with the Environmental
Solutions Initiative at MIT, specifically working
on climate education, mainly

focused on K-12, and even more
specifically on high school. So I develop climate
education materials,

and I'll be talking
more about that later.

DANA DOYLE: Hi. I'm Dana Doyle. I am the director
of the MITx Program, and we support faculty to
make robust, MIT-rigorous,

interactive courses
for the public. And I'll be talking
about those more later.

CURT NEWTON: Thanks. And I'm Curt Newton. I'm director of
MIT OpenCourseWare,

and I also have to admit I
spend a lot of time and energy personally on
climate action work.

And these things which
work at the intersection of open education and open
knowledge and climate action

are near and dear to me, and
I hope they are to you, too. So a few words to
set the context

about what we're about here. Climate change is, as
I'm sure you're aware,

a very large,
multidimensional problem that draws on definitely science
and the things that we know,

but that's not all. Sylvia, what's your
perspective on this?

SYLVIA SCHARF: Well, that
a lot of the time as sort of the background of--
so I would say science communication in general
and climate communication

as a subset of that
has traditionally been this idea that if we shove
enough knowledge and data sets

and graphs at people, that
that will show them the truth. That the way to the truth
is through these data sets

and things like that. And that is one
way to the truth. That is how we know what is
happening scientifically.

We know that carbon
dioxide is rising and that carbon dioxide
acts as a blanket

around our planet,
trapping heat, which is warming all of Earth's systems. And that is changing
our climate.

We know that. But what we also have
started to learn over

the past few years is how
to talk about these things and how to tell these
stories because at base,

we as human are
storytelling beings. Most of us do not, in
fact, think in terms

of graphs and data and numbers. Some of us do, and
we need those folks, but it's not the majority of us.

We think in stories. And so what we
know is just that. I use that very basic
metaphor to explain what

we know about climate change. CURT NEWTON: Yeah,
thanks, Sylvia. And building on what we know,
that foundation, many of us

want to find out what
it is that we can do. And MIT, without a doubt,
has a lot of perspectives

on things that we can do. And that includes applying the
science into new technologies

and technology
solutions and thinking in a rigorous way about how
policies work out in the world.

But that's not all. Climate change is fundamentally
also a very human situation.

And so the things
that we can do, the solutions that we
want to think about, also have a really
important human element.

And in particular, we want to
be keeping in mind the justice

and equity aspects of
these things as well. And so when we think about
what we can do in the solution

space, it's not just
the technology but also

the human and social
aspects of that. SYLVIA SCHARF: We had a
great question in the chat

that a National Academies
committee suggested that psychology and
sociology be studied to reach average citizens
about climate topics.

Absolutely. There's actually a branch of
psychology called conservation psychology which
specifically studies

how to formulate
messaging, communication,

and thinking about how to cause
the kind of behavior change and thought change
that we need in ways

that actually align with how
the human brain really works. So there's really some wonderful
work in the conservation world

and by other people in the
sociology and psychology side of this. And absolutely, I think
that's vitally important.

CURT NEWTON: Yeah, excellent. So when we think about
providing resources

from MIT to learn
about climate, we want to be drawing on
all of these things.

And one last contextual
point that I'd like to make to tee this
up, those of you who

like graphs have
probably seen things like this that
show, for instance,

this is based on United
Nations studies and reports

on the different pathways
that we have before us. And we have a range of pathways.

We're at this juncture
right now where the choices that we make
really matter tremendously.

We have goals to
get global warming limited to well below 2
degrees C per the Paris terms,

as close to 1.5 degrees warming
by the end of the century as we can get. And it's also recognized that
there are other pathways.

In fact, the one that
we're currently on doesn't really
come close to that. It's better than the worst
case scenarios of no climate

policies, but we have a
lot of work still to do. And, in particular,
that work needs

to happen now and in
the next few years. We are here at this
inflection point

among these different
pathways that lead us into the future we need. And so over the
next few decades,

the choices that we make are
really, really going to matter. Without a doubt MIT, is
very focused on educating

the students that
are here right now. But really, I'd say in
this decade in particular,

we need to be bringing
everybody into this conversation and learning all that we
can about climate science

and the different solutions. So whether you're a
student or a teacher or a worker or a
professional, a citizen who's

active as a voter
or an advocate, we want to be
supporting everyone in how they engage in this work.

So I'm curious to know, and
feel free to drop something in the chat about this. What's brought you
here to this talk?

What things are you
interested in learning about? We'd love to know.

With that, let's get into it. What specifically are
these open resources

that are coming from MIT? We're drawing on all
disciplines that are taught here

across the curriculum-- science,
engineering, economics, policy, the humanities.

And we think about the
breadth of the offerings that we've got here, spanning
the full range of things

that people might be
looking for from really engaging introductions that can
come from our trusted sources,

pathways to deepen your
knowledge, in particular, through flexible,
self-paced learning,

and ways to go really deep dive,
build expertise all the way

in through credential-granting,
complete courses. And we'll highlight
a few of these

over the course of the hour. Sylvia. SYLVIA SCHARF: So that idea
of the engaging introduction

is really the core of the
goal of the MIT Climate Portal which can be found
at climate.mit.edu.

And this is an
outwardly-facing page. It's not-- while folks at MIT
absolutely can use it and do,

it is outwardly-facing. The goal of this is to
be used more broadly. And so this includes explainers,
which are basically one-page,

climate science, you
just want to know what is the relationship between
phytoplankton and climate

change, and there's
a one pager on that. You want to understand how
concrete and cement work

in climate change. There's a one pager on that. If you then discover that
your question has not

been answered yet,
you can actually submit a question
to Ask MIT Climate, and we go through
those questions

and pair them to the right
expert to find that answer. So-- and you can also read
through previous questions.

And they really run the gamut
from those seemingly simple questions that are
incredibly complex to I

know this one specific thing
from my realm of expertise. How does it relate
to climate change?

And then we also have a podcast
called TILclimate, which is Today I Learned Climate, and
the goal of the TIL podcast,

TILclimate podcast is that
the episodes are really short. They're under 15 minutes long.

So they're, again,
in that same way of the one-pager, the
quick question, something you could share to
a friend who said,

you know, we were just recently
having that conversation about airplanes and air travel.

Here's a podcast on that. And you're not necessarily
asking them to dive deep into a subject, but
they can learn a lot.

And the podcasts
are conversations with experts in that field. So they're very, very useful
both for that shareability.

You can post them to
your social media. You can send them in
an email to a friend. And they're also, as I'll
talk about later, something

that, because they're aimed
at a general audience, they're also totally
understandable to a high school

through early college audiences. Teachers can use these as
pieces to actually assign

to their students, and
everything is under a Creative Commons license. For example, we are
actually in a partnership

right now with an organization
called Subject to Climate who is actually adapting our
explainers for an interactive

on their website to allow
teachers to ask questions about climate change and get
the answers from our explainers.

So that's one of these ways
that these open access resources are being used across sites.

And then if you want
to dive a little bit deeper but still kind of get
to pick and choose your bets,

we have the Climate Primer. So the Climate Primer
is interactive. It was developed by Dr.
Kerry Emanuel here at MIT.

And you basically
scroll through, and there are
places where there's audio to listen to, a
graph to interact with,

something-- maybe a
question to answer. So it's that step beyond I'm
just going to read something

or I'm just going to
listen to something. And it's a little
bit more interactive, but it's still in chapters. So you can still--

you don't have to go
from A to Z through it. You can still say what
I'm really interested in at this moment is I want to
know how we know what we know.

And there's a chapter on that
within the Climate Primer. And then the work that
I've mostly been working on

for the past year and a
half plus is developing these Educator Guides.

So the Educator Guides are
tied to the TILclimate podcast episodes, but they're not
a guide to the episode.

The idea is that a student
would listen to the episode either as homework or in the
classroom or maybe not at all.

We'd prefer that
they listen to it but it's not necessarily
necessary for doing the activities.

And then teachers can choose
as few or as many activities out of each of these guides
for their students to do.

There's about 3 to 5
activities per guide. They're aimed at a
high school audience, though, depending
on the educator,

you could definitely age
them down to middle school and up to college. They're super flexible.

So it's not you must
do this entire unit, but choose this activity
here, this activity here.

Pull together what you want. And one of the
things that I really wanted to focus on in
this is that they are not

all what you might
call pure science activities because
climate change affects

all parts of human life. And that means that all subjects
can talk about climate change.

So there are
activities in here that can work in an English
classroom, in a math classroom,

in a social studies
or history classroom. You could translate
some of these things into another language
in a language classroom.

There are so many ways to
interact with this work that isn't just looking at graphs
and data and data visualization,

though there are plenty of
data visualizations in there as well because I love them. So these are super useful,
and again, Creative Commons

license. Teachers can remix them,
reshare them, do what they want. We want them to be
out there and usable.

And aging up into more
of the college realm, though some of these activities,
again, could be used,

especially in an upper
high school classroom, my colleague Liz went through
the entire OpenCourseWare,

which Curt will
talk about later, and pulled out every
lesson and activity

that had to do with climate
change or sustainability and put them into this database. So that's fully
searchable, and again,

open source, open
access and as well as all of the explainers
from the MIT Climate Portal.

And she also wrote these
pedagogical practice explainers because there are ways
of teaching that benefit

sustainability learning
better than some other ways of teaching, sort of
standard lecture style.

So there are also
these explainers on best practices around how
to teach this content, not

just what to teach. So the SCALES Project has just
an absolute wealth of material

that you can search
through that database.

CURT NEWTON: Thanks, Sylvia. Speaking for MIT
OpenCourseWare, we love that last one in
particular among all the others.

But just an example
of the sort of adaptations that the Creative
Commons license opens up

to people. And in honor of
International Open Access week, we think that's a
particularly strong message.

So I'm going to talk a little
bit about OpenCourseWare. We've been sharing materials
freely from the MIT curriculum

since 2001, over 20 years now. We've got material from
over 2,500 courses shared

on the MIT OpenCourseWare
website representing all departments and
programs from the most

introductory first year and
even some high school-oriented resources up to some of the
most advanced graduate level

subjects offered on the planet. The focus primarily has
been on teaching materials,

but there's more. Among those teaching
materials, you'll find notes and readings supplied
by the faculty, activities

that they've created,
assessments, problem sets, exams, and so forth. We're also thrilled
to be able to share

student work,
exemplary student work, such as some of
the great projects

that people do here
as inspirations for perhaps things that you
might want to explore yourself.

Additionally, a lot of
videos and a growing amount of videos, that are on OCW. And we've got this
Chalk Radio podcast

where we interview faculty
about the craft of teaching and share their
pedagogical insights.

Those videos on
our YouTube channel are increasingly a powerful
way, a very flexible way,

for people to
discover this content and share it within
their communities.

Over OCW's lifetime,
we think we've reached over 500 million
people around the world.

That's half a
billion, most of whom have come to the website
itself but many more

also through the
redistribution and remixing that Creative Commons enables.

The mode of use for
these users typically is for self-paced
learning, sometimes adapted

into the classrooms, and you
can retain those materials, carry them around with you.

We hear stories of people
who, for instance, don't have reliable internet
access at home.

And so they print
the materials out, and they carry them around
in their back pocket. And they're reading
this stuff as they're

traveling around going
about their business. It's not the most
high tech, but this is the reality of people's lives.

And we're so glad to be able to
support that mode of learning no matter where they are.

Specifically, with regards
to climate change on OCW, we've got over 150 courses.

It's not a bright, hard
line that defines that. Depending on how you count
it, there could be more.

We've put them into
collections themed around the broader topics of
environment and sustainability

and, in particular, the work
that Sylvia's organization, the Environmental
Solutions Initiative,

has done around an undergraduate
minor on these topics. The courses that flow
into that program

we feature in this collection. And with regards to
energy, in a similar vein, the MIT Energy Initiative has
identified a set of courses

that undergraduates can
take to get that minor, and that forms the basis
for our energy collection.

For instance, maybe you're
interested at the-- something about the intersection of
climate change and food.

So just drop into our search
box those couple of terms, and lo and behold, we've
got a course on that.

This is a fairly recent one
taught by Professor Dennis McLaughlin, and you'll find
a description of the course.

Jump over and scan the
syllabus to find out what topics are covered.

We've got some of those
instructor insights that include a podcast interview
with Professor McLaughlin

about how he teaches this and
getting into topics like how do we deal with uncertainty?

Uncertainty runs through
so much of this work and how we learn
and think about it. How do values enter
into the conversation?

Again, a really
fundamental aspect of what it means to be dealing
with climate change nowadays.

And then on into the
materials that are taught, extensive documentation
of what was

covered in each class,
discussion points, readings,

and discussion questions. This is a good example of what
you'll find on OpenCourseWare
for a climate class.  DANA DOYLE: Hi. thank you, Curt.

All right, so I'm going to
preface this a little bit by saying that I refer
to our MITx Program

as open with a small O because
it is not-- the content in here

does not have a Creative
Commons license. But it is available for free
to learn from these courses.

So just to get that clarified. Now, the MITx courses, as I
said, we work with MIT faculty

to develop these courses. They are-- there's a
variety of types of courses. There could be courses that are
parts of courses, courses that

are broken up into modules. But many of our
courses are actually full-length MIT courses.

So they're very, very intense. They have-- we offer
them on edX.org,

and we also recently
launched MITx online. So they're offered
in both places.

Not the same courses
in both places, but some courses on MITx
online and some courses on edX.

You can take the course. The only thing that we normally
have behind an actual paywall

may be a summative
assessment such as an exam. And also, in order to earn
a certificate, if you pass,

you do need to pay
a small fee that helps us to support the
program and to actually build

all these fantastic courses. We also have the
Open Learning Library which is archive material
from MITx content

and also includes some
interactive OCW content. So on there, you may find
content with a Creative Commons

license. It does-- it would be
a little hard in order to use the interactive
part because you actually

need the platform that
supports that interaction. But you can certainly still use
the material in your own way.

On Open Learning Library,
there are no certificates. There's no forum. You don't need to register.

You can just go in and
access the material and take a look at
what you want to do. You can interact with it.

You can get auto graded. If you do want to
save your progress, you do need to have an account
because, obviously, that's

how it knows that that
progress belongs to you. Next slide, please.

Now, in the context
of this presentation, I thought we could highlight
some of the courses

that we have on
energy and climate. We do have-- all
of these courses

are instructor
paced, which means that they start at
a particular time and they end at a
particular time.

So we do have two that
are currently running. So if you wanted to go in
and take a look at them, you can go to-- they're
both on edX.org, one

in energy economics and policy
and one in sustainable energy. And as I said, these
courses are very rigorous.

I-- as an anecdote, my husband,
actually-- he's an architect. And so he was super excited
about the sustainable building

design, and he
started taking it. And then he realized
that they were not

kidding when they said it
was a 12-week course with 13 hours of effort a week, and
he was like, oh, my God.

I just-- I don't have--
he was like it's hard. I'm like, it's an MIT course. I'm like, yes, it is hard. You're absolutely right.

So, as I said, these courses
are not for the faint of heart. But they are very, very
in-depth, and they have--

you will learn a lot. Let me put it that way. And a lot of these actually come
from the organization at MIT

that Curt mentioned
before, MITEI, which is the MIT
Energy Initiative. And they are
seriously considering

different types of programs
and other types of certificates that they could offer. But at the moment, they
do just have these courses

that will offer
you the opportunity to purchase the chance to
get a certificate if you
pass the course. Next slide, please.

One of the great things
about Open edX which really differentiates us from, let's
say, Coursera or even Emeritus

or some courses like
that is that Open edX, which is used both by
edX.org and by MITx Online,

it's an open source
platform, and it has really advanced problem types. So here's a couple of
still images, and if you

can go to the next one, Curt. Oh, and you're going to
be doing the video, too. So the first one, if you take
a look at the sketch tool, just

to show you that perhaps
you've seen something like this, an interactive tool.

But the thing is
that if you do this, it actually will grade you.

And so that, while it
sounds pretty simple, actually getting it to work so
that you can draw on a graph,

it checks your drawing,
and then passes a grade into the course is unusual.

I actually haven't
really seen it in any other type of platform. And so here's a quick
example that just shows you

that you can do the drawing. You can change it. And so this was actually built
by one of our digital learning

lab scientists at MIT. And that's the great thing
about the open source platform is that as our--

the people who build
our courses actually come up with new problem
types and things like that, it actually gets folded
back into the open platform.
Then anybody can use it. So it's really fantastic.

And there we go. And we can skip the next
video, I think, just in the interest of
time and make sure we have time for conversation.

So as I said, the
MITx courses are based on residential courses. And so that means,
in some cases,

they are actual almost one to
one of what is offered on MIT.

But sometimes they want to take
advantage of the scalability, and they want to make
sure that they're including the large audiences
because all of these are MOOCs.

So there can be hundreds
of people taking the course at the same time.

It varies, as I said. Some of them are smaller parts. I would-- I say-- I think the smallest one we
have is a two-week course,

but that's pretty unusual. Usually it's a
full length course, and you can access majority
of the content for free.

It's all the learning
is available for free. That is one of the things. And in some courses,
we actually have exceptions where the
exams are also free

if it really is important
for the pedagogical nature of the course.

And if you make
a small payment-- and I would say for a
full length MIT course, the cost is usually
about $99 or $149,

and that then allows you
to access the final exam and to get the
certificate if you pass.

And as we mentioned
before, we do have some archives available on
Open Learning Library that you

can access at any time. I'll check on that, thank
you-- the Kerry Emanuel course.

CURT NEWTON: Yeah, the Kerry
Emanuel course, there's an archived version on
Open Learning Library.

DANA DOYLE: Yeah,
usually there should be. I'll have to check what the link
says because sometimes, I don't know why it would be broken.

It should still go
somewhere, but I'll check it. CURT NEWTON: All
right, so now we wanted to walk through
a few examples of how

different kinds
of learners might engage in these materials.

Let's start with maybe a
team of high school science and social studies teachers.

Sylvia, you want
to run with that? SYLVIA SCHARF:
Yeah, so one, when

teachers are building their
curriculum for the year, especially I think often social
studies teachers will often

look at what's going
on in the world and try to base some of their
subject matter around there.

And let's say it's been a
particularly bad hurricane year or there have been hurricanes
in the other way-- in--

and so they can start
with they realize

the science teacher maybe
understands some things about the relationship between
sea surface temperature and hurricane ferocity.

But the social studies
teacher really hasn't. So they go to the
Climate Portal. They type in hurricanes,
and they get an article

from Ask MIT Climate. They get a TILclimate episode,
and they get an explainer.

So they read those. They listen to them,
and they realize, oh, we could assign some of
these to our students.

And so perhaps they assign
listening to the TILclimate episode to their
students, and there's also

a full transcript for every
episode of TILclimate. So for students for
whom it's easier to read

or they intake information
better visually, that's available. And then they realize, oh,
there's an educator guide.

They click on the
educator guide, and there are a bunch of
activities in the educator guide.

Not all of them are applicable
to what they're doing, but some of them are. So they can get that guide
as-- and the guides come with--

they're both what the students
will be able to do at the end. If you keep scrolling
down you can

see what standards it's
tied to at the high school level for both Next Generation
Science Standards and Common

Core standards. And this has four different
activities, one of which is more directly science
oriented and one of which--

the next one is about
language and the language we use to talk about hurricanes. So all of a sudden
now they've got

things they can bring
to their students to talk about this topical
issue in the classroom that

is ready to go.  And that can kind be the
beginning of, perhaps,

including more climate change
across their topic area. But at the moment, given
how little climate change

is being taught in schools,
this would be amazing. CURT NEWTON: Yeah.

And so you mentioned the
climate science and risk primer which Kerry Emanuel
also wrote which

would be a wonderful
next step transition. And then there was-- SYLVIA SCHARF: And
something that teachers

have assigned to their
students as well as something they can interact with. CURT NEWTON: Yeah, maybe I'll
just call that up for a second

so people can see
what that's like. SYLVIA SCHARF: So that's
just climateprimer.mit.edu. CURT NEWTON: It's in there?

SYLVIA SCHARF: Yeah, it's
sort of in the Climate Portal but not entirely. So climate-- yeah, there we go.

So-- and if you scroll
down, you can actually see there's an
introduction, but then there

are a bunch of chapters. So, again, you could
start with the beginning, or you can say I
just really want

to understand how
the atmosphere works. And you can see
these animations,

callouts of the key
pieces of information. And, again, if you
pause on that animation,

you'll see that it is both
downloadable and shareable. So, again, it's open access.

It's something that
you can snag and throw into a PowerPoint presentation
or however you are sharing.
CURT NEWTON: Yeah, love that.

Anything else on the ESI
materials, on this Sylvia? SYLVIA SCHARF: Yeah,
I mean, I think

there are all-- there are so
many different ways to interact with it. And I think that that
really gives flexibility

for teachers who
are differentiating their classrooms as well. So there are some
students who are going to do better being
assigned something to read.

Others are going to
listen, and then they can teach each other
what they learned. The explainer on hurricanes
and the podcast on hurricanes

cover very similar topics
but from different angles. Then they teach each
other, and now there's a whole bunch of learning that's
happening in that classroom.

CURT NEWTON: Yeah, great. I'll just take a moment
since this was asked about.
Let's see-- Emanuel.

Yeah, so this is what
the Open Learning Library site for Kerry Emanuel's global
warming science course is like.

And you can jump in if
you want to really get in deep with Kerry's
teaching, and it's all
available here for you as well.

Next scenario was a-- imagine a working professional,
maybe somebody who's

worked in technology but not
specifically around climate and associated fields,
wants to explore

the broad field of
renewable energy as perhaps a growth opportunity.

As our high school
teaching team did, the Climate Portal would
be a wonderful place

to start on that. Sylvia, what might
they start with here? SYLVIA SCHARF: Renewable.

You'll get quite a few. Yep, 660 results, plenty
to get me going on with.

But there is definitely--
there is an explainer, and that just goes through the
discussion of it literally.

I love this graphic
here because it just defines the terms
of the difference

between renewable and low
carbon because those are not the same words, though they
are often used interchangeably.

And also from here, actually,
if you scroll up a little bit, there are a bunch of
connections on the right hand

side of the screen
to other resources. So you start on the explainer,
and it's already popping you

off to a bunch of other things. For example, the US Energy
Information Administration which, by the way, if you love

SYLVIA SCHARF: I'm
noticing Elizabeth has a question about looking
at what individual actions

people can do. And I think my overall
message is find a group.

Join with others. Find the work that you want
to do that others are doing

and you can join. The focus on individual
actions is really

something that takes the
pressure off the places where the policy needs to be.

There's-- going back, actually,
to that first question about the idea of our
understanding of psychology,

there is a psychological
phenomenon called the single action bias. And it means that
within our brains,

and this can be for any topic. It can be from I want to
keep my house cleaner. I want to be eating
more vegetables.

Whatever it is that you're
setting for yourself, there is a certain
part of our brain

that basically once we've done
one thing towards that thing kind of checks it off and
moves on to the other things

that we also-- are also
important in our lives. And so single actions on
climate have that same effect.

For decades, we really
focused on pushing turning off the lights and recycling.

And if those single actions
had the effect we wanted, we would be in a very different
world today than we are.

And, in fact, what we
found is that that focus on single actions
actually reduces energy available for the
larger communal actions that
need to happen. So my overall thing is don't. Go find the group.

Find the people who are doing
the work that excites you. Find the organizations whose
work aligns with your values,

your interests, and what
brings you joy, and join them.

CURT NEWTON:
Couldn't agree more. Love it.
